The name of the organic substituent of each molecule is written below its chemical structure. TS0.8 (□), Sb2O3 (△), and no catalyst (○). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Comparison of the conversion of bis(2-hydroxyethyl)terephthalate at 30 min of microwave-assisted polycondensation for different TiO2/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Conversion of bis(2-hydroxyethyl)terephthalate at 30 min of microwave-assisted polycondensation against the composition of the precursor solution. TS-dodecyl (◼) and TS-phenylethyl ( ). The spectrum of the trimethoxyphenylethylsilane precursor is also shown for comparison. *Rotational sidebands. The catalyst composition was estimated from the TGA results. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 a) Surface composition compared with the composition of the precursor solution and b) the binding energy of Ti 2p3/2 plotted against the surface composition. Microwave-assisted polycondensation for screening of organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts Ashutosh Thakur Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Visualization Data curation Writing - original draft Takuya Hamamoto Investigation Formal analysis Tomohiro Ikeda Investigation Validation Patchanee Chammingkwan Visualization Toru Wada Formal analysis Toshiaki Taniike Resources Conceptualization Supervision Writing - review & editing * Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 1-1 Asahidai, Nomi, Ishikawa 923-1292, Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology 1-1 Asahidai Nomi Ishikawa 923-1292 Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 1-1 Asahidai, Nomi, Ishikawa 923-1292, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Development of efficient and environmental-friendly solid catalysts is an important target for polyester production. Herein, we report a novel screening strategy based on microwave-assisted polycondensation and its application for exploring organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts with varied chemical composition and organic functionality. Modification of TiO2/SiO2 catalysts with specific organic groups resulted in superior polycondensation performance at a reduced amount of titanium. Among these, phenylethyl modification was found to be most promising, which exhibited at least 9 and 19 times higher activity than industrial TiO2/SiO2 and Sb2O3 catalysts. The phenylethyl modification during coprecipitation led to smaller catalyst particles with improved hydrophobicity, and the dilution of surface titanium sites by silicon atoms for enhanced Lewis acidity. Synergistic combination of these positive consequences realized the high activity of the developed catalyst, particularly at low temperature. Keywords Polyester TiO2/SiO2catalyst Organic modification Microwave-assisted polycondensation Catalyst screening 1 Introduction Polyesters represent an important class of thermoplastic materials, which are featured with low cost, high transparency, and excellent mechanical as well as thermal properties [1]. Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) has the largest production volume among all polyesters. It is widely used for synthetic fibers, packaging materials, and beverage bottles. Industrial synthesis of PET is implemented based on a two-step polymerization process [2,3]. The first step is direct esterification of terephthalic acid or trans esterification of dimethylterephthalate with ethylene glycol to produce mainly a diester, namely bis(2-hydroxyethyl)terephthalate. The second step is catalytic polycondensation of the esterification product. The polycondensation is an energy intensive process, as it requires the removal of a condensation byproduct to prevent depolymerization. Typically, it is performed above the melting point of PET at 280 °C under a reduced pressure in the presence of a suitable catalyst. The efficiency of PET production has been improved by sophistication in the polymerization process and development of new catalysts [4]. In particular, development of efficient catalysts for the polycondensation reaction is still considered as an important industrial target. Antimony oxide (Sb2O3) is the most widely used catalyst because of its balanced activity, polymer properties, and cost. Germanium oxide is also a well-known catalyst for its high activity [3,4]. However, there are serious environmental and safety concerns associated with antimony-based catalysts, while the high cost of germanium restricts its use in the industrial production of PET [4–6]. Then, titanium-based catalysts have emerged as promising alternatives due to their high activity, low cost, and low toxicity [3,4,7]. In the early stage of research, molecular catalysts such as titanium alkoxides were studied, which indeed displayed remarkable activity in the polycondensation reaction. However, serious drawbacks were simultaneously found. These are propensities i) to undergo hydrolysis and gradually lose activity during polycondensation, ii) to promote degradation reactions, which deteriorate thermal and hydrolytic stability of the product, and iii) to impart a yellow color to the product [4,8]. In order to overcome these drawbacks, efforts were devoted to design new ligands for titanium-based molecular catalysts [9–11]. In contrast, Acordis developed the first solid polycondensation catalyst, which is a TiO2/SiO2 coprecipitate and known by the trade name C94 [12,13]. This catalyst displays superior activity and causes less environmental impacts in comparison to Sb2O3 [3]. Also, the polymer produced by C94 possess improved hydrolytic stability and reduced color in comparison to that produced by titanium alkoxides [8]. Nonetheless, C94 as a solid catalyst would reduce the dispersion of titanium in the polymerization medium, which should be considered for further improvement of its performance. However, there had been limited academic efforts attempting to develop new titanium-based solid catalysts with superior dispersion. The lack of studies regarding the fundamental understanding of solid polycondensation catalysts is also critical for the said development. In this respect, organic modification of TiO2/SiO2 catalysts to improve their dispersion and detailed characterization to account for their working principle seem promising, which have never been done before. The development of a performant catalyst requires the exploration of a huge parametric space by repetitive catalyst preparation and catalytic tests [14,15]. Here, we attempt to develop a new class of organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 solid polycondensation catalysts by introducing an efficient screening protocol. This protocol combines parallel catalyst preparation, microwave (MW)-assisted polycondensation as a tool for catalyst screening, and a quick method to evaluate the activity of a catalyst with the aid of gas chromatography. In recent years, MW-assisted polymerization has gained increasing attention due to the ability of MW irradiation to greatly enhance the reaction rate in comparison to conventional heating [16,17]. The rate enhancement is mainly attributed to the instantaneous, rapid, and uniform heating under MW irradiation. Besides, MW irradiation often leads to improved selectivity by suppressing undesired side reactions owing to short reaction time and elimination of wall effects [18]. Velmathi et al. demonstrated the successful synthesis of bio-based aliphatic polyesters using MW irradiation, where a drastic rate enhancement by MW was observed [19]. Nonetheless, the use of MW irradiation as a tool for the screening of catalysts in PET synthesis has been rarely demonstrated. In this contribution, we report MW-assisted polycondensation for the screening of solid catalysts with varied chemical composition and organic functionality. The screening results were validated by a conventional polycondensation process, and multilateral characterization was performed to understand the role of organic modification on catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Titanium tetra-n-butoxide (Ti(OnBu)4, ≥97.0 %) was received from Kanto Chemical Co., Inc. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (Si(OEt)4, >96.0 %), triethoxymethylsilane (>98.0 %), triethoxypropylsilane (>98.0 %), hexyltriethoxysilane (>97.0 %), dodecyltriethoxysilane (>95.0 %), cyclohexyltrimethoxysilane (>97.0 %), triethoxyphenylsilane (>99.0 %), benzyltriethoxysilane (>96.0 %), trimethoxyphenylethylsilane (mixture of 1- and 2-phenylethyl, >95.0 %), triethoxyvinylsilane (>98.0 %), bis(2-hydroxyethyl)terephthalate (BHET, >85.0 %), and tetrakis(trimethylsilyl)silane (TKS, >98.0 %) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. BHET was used in the form of powder after crushing the as-received BHET pellets on a blender and sieving on a 500 μm mesh. Ethylene glycol (EG, >99.5 %) and ethanol (>99.5 %) were obtained from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A library of catalysts was prepared based on coprecipitation of metal alkoxides and according to a patent with minor modification [13]. The unmodified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts are represented in the form of TS x , where T and S stand for TiO2 and SiO2, and the subscript x corresponds to the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio that was employed in the preparation of a catalyst. The catalyst preparation was performed on a parallel reactor system (Fig. 1 ) modified from Syncore Analyst (Buchi), whose detailed specifications were described in our previous paper [20]. Briefly, the reactor system is equipped with multiple mechanical stirrers for the parallel execution of 24 reactions under N2 in glass tubes, each with the maximum working volume of 30 mL. The tubes can be charged with reagents before and during the reaction under controlled atmosphere through injection ports which are placed at the top of the cover heads of all the tubes. For the synthesis of a TS x catalyst, a precursor solution was prepared in ethanol, which contained Ti(OnBu)4 and Si(OEt)4 at a Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio specified as x and at a fixed (Ti + Si) concentration of 0.4 mmol/mL. Then, a 10 mL of H2O/ethanol (1/10, v/v) was added to 10 mL of the precursor solution through the injection port with continuous stirring at 30 °C and the reaction continued for 1.0 h. The obtained coprecipitate was separated by centrifugation, washed three times with deionized water, and dried in vacuo for several hours at 70 °C. Organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the same procedure, where a variety of organotrialkoxysilanes were employed instead of Si(OEt)4. They included different organic substituents such as linear and cyclic alkyl substituents, aryl-containing substituents, and a vinyl substituent, whose chemical structures are represented in Fig. 2 . The prepared catalysts are termed as TS x -F, where F corresponds to the name of the organic substituent. 2.3 Catalytic test In order to improve the throughput of catalytic tests, MW-assisted polycondensation was employed. It was performed on a MW synthesizer (CEM Discover SP, Explorer 72) equipped with a robotic arm to execute 72 MW-assisted reactions in sequence under various isothermal and constant power conditions. From preliminary experiments, we found that the polycondensation yield was more reproducible when the MW power rather than the reaction temperature was controlled. Hence, MW-assisted bulk polycondensation of BHET was conducted under a constant power mode using an optimized two-step irradiation protocol. In a typical experiment, e.g. run 1 in Table 1 , a 10 mL glass vial was charged with BHET (3.5 g) and the catalyst (5.0 mg) under N2, which was then sealed with a septum to entrap the formed EG during the polycondensation reaction. Thereafter, the tube was irradiated with MW at 20 W for 10 min to melt the BHET and subsequently irradiated at 10 W for 30 min to perform the reaction. After completion, the resultant polymer was dissolved in 25 mL of phenol/1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane (1/1, v/v), and 0.5 mL of this polymer solution was poured into 25 mL of methanol. Then, EG in this methanol was analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (GC-FID) to determine the EG yield. Since the formation of a new ester bond accompanies the liberation of one EG molecule as the byproduct, the amount of BHET consumed, in principle, is equivalent to the amount of EG produced. This fact was confirmed by performing MW-assisted polycondensation of BHET using two different catalysts, Sb2O3 and TS0.8. The formed polymer was recovered by precipitation from methanol to determine the polymer yield. The results are shown in Fig. S1, in which the average EG yield (or the monomer conversion) was found to be quantitatively consistent to the average polymer yield, while the EG yield provided a better throughput and accuracy. 2.4 Polycondensation by conventional heating For the validation of catalyst screening results, polycondensation of BHET was also performed by conventional heating under a vacuum condition. In a typical experiment, e.g. run 65 in Table 3, a Schlenk tube was charged with BHET (2.0 g) and the catalyst (1.0 mg) under N2. The Schlenk tube was vertically placed in an electrically heated aluminium block bath and connected with a vacuum pump, a mercury manometer to record pressure, and a thermocouple to record temperature during the reaction. The temperature was increased from 25 to 220 °C over a period of 50 min under a normal pressure of N2 and a constant stirring of 350 rpm. During this period, BHET completely melted to form a transparent liquid. Thereafter, the vacuum was applied at a reduced pressure of 15 mmHg to execute the polycondensation. The reaction time was recorded immediately after the vacuum was applied. After the desired time, the reaction mixture was cooled under N2. The polymer yield was determined based on the method explained in the earlier section. 2.5 Characterization Selected catalysts were characterized by several techniques. To confirm successful organic modification, solid-state 13C CP/MAS NMR and Fourier transformed infrared (FTIR) measurements were performed. 13C CP/MAS NMR was recorded at 125.8 MHz on a Bruker AVANCE III 500 MHz spectrometer. Powder samples were ground with TKS at the ratio of 9/1 wt/wt and tightly packed into a 4 mm MAS rotor made of ZrO. The MAS frequency was set at 8 kHz, the number of accumulations was 10000, and the contact time for each cross-polarization (CP) was 2 ms. The 13C chemical shifts were internally referenced to the CH3 peak of TKS at 3.517 ppm. FTIR spectra were acquired in the transmission mode on a JASCO FT/IR-6100 spectrometer. The samples were prepared by the KBr method and the spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–1000 cm–1 with a resolution of 4 cm–1 and 24 accumulations. The amount of organic groups present in a catalyst was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Rigaku TG8121) under dry air. A powder sample was heated up to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and held for 10 min to completely remove adsorbed water before being subjected to further heat treatment up to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The particle morphology of a catalyst was observed on a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4100) working at an accelerated voltage of 20 kV. A powder sample was attached on a carbon tape and subjected to Pt sputtering before SEM measurements. The surface chemical analysis was performed based on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XPS spectra were acquired on a Kratos AXIS-Ultra DLD spectrometer using monochromatic Al-Kα radiation. The pass energy of the concentric hemispherical analyzer was set at 40 eV. A narrow scan was recorded in 240 s with a step increment of 0.1 eV and repeated at least 5 times for each element. Powder samples were loaded on a sample holder through double-sided adhesive copper tape. The binding energies (BE) were calibrated using the C 1s peak of surface hydrocarbons at 285.0 eV as the internal reference. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening Rapid heating by MW irradiation often makes it difficult to capture the difference of activity among different catalysts within the time scale of the experiment, as the reaction quickly converges to a steady-state regime. Therefore, it was necessary to optimize MW irradiation conditions in order to acquire an appropriate kinetic profile for a catalyst. Accordingly, MW-assisted polycondensation of BHET (5.0 g) was performed in the absence of a catalyst and in the presence of Sb2O3 (5.0 mg) or TS0.8 (5.0 mg). The major findings of these preliminary experiments are described as follows. The MW-assisted polycondensation was much faster than the polycondensation based on conventional heating, where the power of MW was found to be the more reliable parameter than the reaction temperature. The polycondensation in a closed system typically accompanied a rapid increment of the monomer conversion followed by the convergence towards a plateau due to the polymerization/depolymerization equilibrium. An example is shown in Fig. 3 a, where 300 W MW irradiation was applied for 3–15 min. It can be seen that the reaction quickly attained the equilibrium within 5–10 min of irradiation, suggesting that MW irradiation of lower energy was necessary to more clearly observe the difference of activity between the employed catalysts. After a series of experiments, a two-step MW irradiation protocol was introduced, in which the reaction mixture was first irradiated at 20 W for 10 min in order to melt BHET, followed by irradiation at 10 W to perform the polycondensation. The reaction time was recorded immediately after completion of the first 20 W irradiation (Fig. S2). The results are shown in Fig. 3b. It was found that the rise of conversion became much slower, where the reaction slowly proceeded towards the equilibrium over 30 min of irradiation. The activity of the two catalysts can be clearly differentiated in the first 30 min of irradiation, where TS0.8 exhibited obviously higher activity than Sb2O3 in accordance with earlier research [21]. The role of a catalyst was evident by the much lower conversion obtained in the absence of a catalyst. All the reactions in Fig. 3b were reproducible with a reasonable error range, suggesting uniform melting of BHET and negligible loss of formed EG in the closed system. The two-step MW irradiation protocol was employed in the following screening experiments. MW-assisted polycondensation of BHET was conducted using a series of unmodified (TS x ) and organically-modified (TS x -F) catalysts (x = 0.8, 0.6), where the EG yields were respectively measured at 30 and 60 min of irradiation. Ti(OnBu)4 and pure TiO2 (TS1) were also tested as references. The results are summarized in Table 1. It was found that the maximum conversion was limited to approximately 40 mol% due to the previously explained polycondensation equilibrium in a closed system. The equilibrium conversion was attained at 60 min of MW irradiation for a majority of the catalysts. On the other hand, the conversion values at 30 min were mostly lower than 40 mol% and widely different among the catalysts. This suggested the feasibility of catalyst screening based on the conversion value at 30 min. Ti(OnBu)4 achieved the maximum conversion at 30 min due to its superior dispersion and high atom utilization efficiency. Pure TiO2 (TS1) deteriorated the conversion to 25.2 mol%, while the inclusion of SiO2 improved the conversion to 31.8 mol% (TS0.8). Further increase of the silicon fraction significantly deteriorated the conversion to 17.3 mol% (TS0.6). All these results were consistent with the original invention for C94 [8,13,21]. The conversion value at 30 min is compared among all the TS-F catalysts in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that the conversion was strongly influenced by the organic substituent of alkoxysilanes. Modification with short alkyl groups including the vinyl group deteriorated the conversion with respect to unmodified TS0.8. The conversion was greatly improved by elongating the length of the alkyl chain, where TS-dodecyl resulted in the maximum conversion at 30 min irrespective of the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio (x). On the other hand, modification with the cyclohexyl and aryl groups consistently led to a higher conversion at 30 min in comparison to TS0.8. Among these, phenylethyl modification led to the maximum conversion within the equilibrium at 30 min irrespective of the x value. Another important finding was that the lower Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio (i.e. x = 0.6) gave the higher conversion for most of the organically-modified catalysts, while it was opposite for the unmodified catalysts. The origin of this observation will be discussed later. In summary, organic modification of TiO2/SiO2 catalysts was found to be effective for improving their polycondensation performance at a lower titanium content. In Fig. 4, performant catalysts such as TS-dodecyl and TS-phenylethyl exhibited the maximum conversion within the equilibrium even at 30 min of MW irradiation. Therefore, the amount of a catalyst in the MW-assisted polycondensation was reduced from 5.0 mg to 1.0 mg (smallest reliable amount) to determine the difference of activity of these catalysts. The results are included in Table 2 for Sb2O3, TS0.8, TS0.8-dodecyl, and TS0.8-phenylethyl. By reducing the amount of a catalyst, Sb2O3 and TS0.8 did not acquire the maximum conversion even at 60 min. In contrast, TS0.8-dodecyl and TS0.8-phenylethyl resulted in the maximum conversion at 60 min, again confirming their superior activity over Sb2O3 and TS0.8. The comparison of the conversion value at 30 min successfully differentiated the activity difference of these two catalysts, where TS0.8-phenylethyl exhibited the conversion almost twice that of TS0.8-dodecyl. Then, the second-stage screening was performed using 1.0 mg of TS x -dodecyl and TS x -phenylethyl (x = 0.8–0.2) with the intention to lower the titanium content in a catalyst, which is recognized as a source of polymer discoloration [22]. The results are summarized in Table 2. Again, the maximum conversion was attained at 60 min of MW irradiation, so that the conversion at 30 min was compared among different x values (Fig. 5 ). In the case of TS-dodecyl, the highest conversion was identified at x = 0.4. On the other hand, TS-phenylethyl exhibited the highest conversion at the smallest x value, confirming the highest activity of TS0.2-phenylethyl among all the employed catalysts in the polycondensation reaction. It turned out that the conversion for TS0.2-phenylethyl at 30 min (run 63) was 19.9 times greater than that for Sb2O3, and 9.9 times greater than that for TS0.8 even though the titanium fraction was greatly reduced. Such a remarkable improvement of activity by organic modification had never been reported for the catalytic polycondensation of BHET. 3.2 Validation of screening results The screening results were validated based on the polycondensation of BHET under a reduced pressure by conventional heating at 220 °C, where two most representative catalysts, TS0.8 and TS0.2-phenylethyl, were employed. The results are summarized in Table 3. The continuous removal of EG under a reduced pressure made the polymer yields much greater than the conversion obtained using MW irradiation in a closed system. Nonetheless, the activity of TS0.2-phenylethyl was far superior to that of TS0.8: It took 60 min for TS0.8 to acquire the yield over 80 %, while only 10 min was required for TS0.2-phenylethyl. Thus, the screening results were found to be valid even in a conventional process. The prominent activity of TS0.2-phenylethyl may be useful to lower the temperature of the polycondensation, as can be seen in a sufficiently high yield at 200 °C only within 20 min (run 69). 3.3 Catalyst characterization In order to apprehend the positive influence of organic modification on the polycondensation performance, TS and TS-phenylethyl catalysts with different Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratios were characterized by several techniques. Successful organic modification was confirmed by solid-state 13C CP/MAS NMR (Fig. 6 ) and FTIR (Fig. S3). In Fig. 6, the 13C NMR spectrum of the alkoxysilane precursor in its two isomeric forms is also shown for comparison. The catalysts exhibited broad NMR peaks, typical for solid-state NMR. These peaks appeared at the identical positions with those of the alkoxysilane precursor, thus straightforwardly assigned to the carbons of the 1- and 2-phenylethyl groups. Moreover, the peaks corresponding to the methoxy groups were not observed in the spectra of the catalysts, assuring that the phenylethyl groups were derived from the reacted precursor rather than unwashed one. The FTIR spectra of the TS-phenylethyl catalysts further confirmed successful organic modification based on absorption bands ascribed to CC vibration (1455 and 1496 cm–1) and CH stretching (2920 and 3032 cm–1). It can be also noticed that absorption bands related to adsorbed H2O molecules (1635 and 3380 cm–1) were much weaker for TS-phenylethyl than for unmodified TS catalysts. Hence, the organic modification improved the hydrophobicity of the catalysts. In fact, the TS-phenylethyl catalysts were dispersed in the hexane phase of a water-hexane biphasic system, while the unmodified TS catalysts remained in the water phase (Fig. S4). Fig. 7 a shows TGA results, where the catalysts were dehydrated at 200 °C for 10 min and the subsequent weight loss up to 600 °C was compared. For the unmodified TS catalysts, the weight loss was insensitive to the composition, falling in the range of 2–4%. On the other hand, the weight loss was much greater for the TS-phenylethyl catalysts. It increased along with the decrease in the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio. Here, the weight loss was reasonably ascribed primarily to the decomposition of organic groups and secondly to the removal of surface hydroxyl groups. Then, the weight percentage of phenylethyl groups contained in the catalysts could be approximated by W t % o f p h e n y l e t h y l g r o u p s = W L T S x - p h e n y l e t h y l - W L T S x On the other hand, the same percentage is theoretically derived as W t % o f p h e n y l e t h y l g r o u p s = 1 - y M P h e n y l e t h y l - 0.5 M O y M T i O 2 + 1 - y M S i O 1.5 + 1 - y M p h e n y l e t h y l x 100 where y corresponds to the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio in a catalyst and M corresponds to the molar mass of individual components. The combination of these two equations allowed us to estimate the chemical composition of the TS-phenylethyl catalysts. Fig. 7b compares the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio for the catalyst with the same mole ratio for the precursor solution. The deviation in the composition between the catalyst and precursor solution depended on the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio of the precursor solution (x). At x = 0.8, the catalyst composition was consistent with that of the precursor solution, indicating that the titanium and silicon precursors were equally precipitated. However, the catalyst composition became more deviated in a way to incorporate a smaller amount of the alkoxysilane precursor at a lower x value. The alkoxysilane precursor is less reactive, and a non-negligible fraction remained unreacted at a lower x value, which was eventually removed during washing. As earlier stated, the dispersibility of solid particles in a highly viscous medium of bulk polycondensation is an important issue for designing an efficient solid catalyst. The utilization of organotrialkoxysilanes instead of tetraalkoxysilane during coprecipitation was expected to be advantageous not only in terms of improved hydrophobicity but also for diminishing the particle size of catalysts owing to the lower reactivity and capping ability of organotrialkoxysilanes [23–25]. SEM images were thus acquired for TS x and TS x -phenylethyl catalysts at x = 0.8 and 0.2. The results are shown in Fig. 8 . All the catalysts afforded nearly spherical particles, while the particle size varied in the range of 100–500 nm, depending on the type of the alkoxysilane precursor and its fraction. As expected, the addition of less reactive alkoxysilanes decreased the particle size as a result of slower growth during the coprecipitation. This tendency was more pronounced for trimethoxyphenylethylsilane, supporting the superiority of TS x -phenylethyl to unmodified TS catalysts. The Lewis acidity of surface titanium is important for a condensation reaction [26,27]. XPS analysis was performed for a series of TS x and TS x -phenylethyl catalysts. The results are summarized in Table 4 . It can be seen that the surface Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio decreased along with the decrease in the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio of the precursor solution. At the same time, the binding energy of Ti 2p peaks shifted towards a higher energy side due to the inclusion of more electronegative silicon atoms. Again, these tendencies were found to be more pronounced for the TS-phenylethyl catalysts. Further information is extracted by plotting the surface Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio against the Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio of the precursor solution (Fig. 9 a). For both types of the catalysts, the surface composition deviated from that of the precursor solution at a higher x value. As was already mentioned, this was due to the incomplete conversion of less reactive alkoxysilane precursors. On the other hand, the extent of the deviation was smaller for less reactive trimethoxyphenylethylsilane, which could be attributed to its capping action. Indeed, the surface composition of the TS-phenylethyl catalysts was consistently richer in silicon atoms than their bulk composition (Fig. 9a vs. 7b). Fig. 9b shows the binding energy of the Ti 2p3/2 peak plotted against the surface Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio. It was found that both types of the catalysts followed the nearly identical trend. The dilution of surface titanium atoms by silicon atoms withdraw electrons from the titanium atoms to make them more Lewis acidic [28,29]. In the case of TS-phenylethyl, the dilution reached a higher level due to the capping role of organotrialkoxysilanes, as a result of which the titanium atoms became more electron deficient. 3.4 Role of organic modification on catalytic performance From the characterization results, the activity enhancement of TiO2/SiO2 catalysts by organic modification can be attributed to the synergistic combination of the following three factors: i) Improved hydrophobicity, ii) smaller particle size, and iii) higher Lewis acidity of surface titanium sites. It was considered that the factors (i) and (ii) improved the dispersion of catalyst particles in the polymerization medium, while the factor (iii) enhanced the interaction between titanium sites and growing PET chains, thus accelerating the rate of polycondensation [4]. In addition, it was also likely that the factor (ii) increased the number of titanium sites those were accessible for growing PET chains in the polycondensation reaction. All these factors were more pronounced for the organically-modified catalysts at a lower Ti/(Ti + Si) mole ratio (x), which accounts for the improvement of their polycondensation performance with the decrease in the x value (Fig. 4). Even though a minor reduction in the particle size and an improvement in the Lewis acidity of surface titanium sites were observed for the unmodified TS catalysts with the decrease in the x value, these were plausibly not sufficient to improve the polycondensation performance over TS0.8. Rather, the reduction in the number of titanium sites with the decrease in x below 0.8 plausibly became detrimental for the unmodified TS catalysts. 4 Conclusions The promising activity, stability, and low toxicity of titanium-based solid polycondensation catalysts prompted us to develop a new class of organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts with superior dispersion. To explore a parametric space of catalyst materials, we introduced an efficient screening protocol based on parallel catalyst preparation, microwave-assisted polycondensation of bis(2-hydroxyethyl)terephthalate in a closed system, and a quick method to evaluate the performance of a catalyst. A variety of TiO2/SiO2 catalysts with different organic functionality and chemical composition were subjected to catalyst screening. Organic modification with sufficiently long linear alkyl, cyclic alkyl, and aryl groups resulted in superior polycondensation performance in comparison to unmodified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts. From the screening results, phenylethyl-modified catalysts appeared to be most promising in terms of their ability to maintain high polycondensation performance at a significantly reduced amount of titanium. These results were successfully validated by a conventional polycondensation process. A detailed characterization study was implemented to understand the working principle of TiO2/SiO2 solid polycondensation catalysts. It was revealed that the hydrophobic nature, small particle size, and high Lewis acidity of surface titanium sites are important for enhancing the polycondensation activity. These properties can be tuned through the type and fraction of the organotrialkoxysilane precursor in the coprecipitation of metal alkoxides. On the basis of the findings of this research, we have successfully demonstrated MW-assisted polycondensation as an effective tool for the screening of performant solid polycondensation catalysts. The results demonstrated here are expected to greatly augment the development of efficient and less harmful solid catalysts for the industrial polyester production. coredata.dc:description: Development of efficient and environmental-friendly solid catalysts is an important target for polyester production. Herein, we report a novel screening strategy based on microwave-assisted polycondensation and its application for exploring organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts with varied chemical composition and organic functionality. Modification of TiO2/SiO2 catalysts with specific organic groups resulted in superior polycondensation performance at a reduced amount of titanium. Among these, phenylethyl modification was found to be most promising, which exhibited at least 9 and 19 times higher activity than industrial TiO2/SiO2 and Sb2O3 catalysts. The phenylethyl modification during coprecipitation led to smaller catalyst particles with improved hydrophobicity, and the dilution of surface titanium sites by silicon atoms for enhanced Lewis acidity. Synergistic combination of these positive consequences realized the high activity of the developed catalyst, particularly at low temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Microwave-assisted polycondensation for screening of organically-modified TiO2/SiO2 catalysts
